body: Is this reviewable? If so, please fix your commit message to make it readable. See commit guidelines. Furthermore please make sure the tests actually can run, include the right packages for ci.
Please review your commit message.
@bolkedebruin Can you review this?

@bolkedebruin  the previous definition was not used anywhere in the application. even if it was being used..it would have been overridden by the second __init__. 
anyway, am going to create another pull request and hope the CI is trigged.  

edit: didn't see the CI build failure. will look into it.

edit: i went through the code, looks like SimpleDag is created only at two places. and it is using the updated def. 

https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/jobs.py#L1768
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/tests/jobs.py#L936

was trying to rerun the travic ci. got error abuse reported. 
![travic-ci-abuse](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4460062/31882584-e16f221e-b804-11e7-8d58-e788ce4236e0.PNG)
@Fokko can this be merged now?
@rupesh92 I've reviewed and merged it.
Spotify uses [his own pipeline tool](https://github.com/spotify/luigi). How can be posible that they also uses Airflow? Any reference on this?

Dunno. I thought that they standardized his tools and the whole company uses the same one.

@bolkedebruin we are still chugging away at our [list of things](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/x/TpBjB) needed for the first release in[ this branch](https://github.com/bloomberg/airflow/tree/airflow-kubernetes-executor).

@dimberman can give you more updates, but it would probably be useful to chat about some of the design tradeoffs being made at some point. IE) I know there was an outstanding question about whether using a docker image created/maintained by google [gcr.io/google-containers/git-sync-amd64] in an apache project is OK to do or not (among other questions)
I think the correct name is qds-sdk: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/qds_sdk

@ reviewer - As part of a larger design decision, how should we think about naming hooks extending the AwsHook base class?

e.g. here we name the file "AwsLambda", but elsewhere we call it by the service name without the "Aws" prefix - "S3Hook" instead of "AwsS3Hook". This is also relevant for the RedshiftHook PR (https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2717): "AwsRedshiftHook" vs. "RedshiftHook".

Just want to make sure our naming is consistent!

@andyxhadji I concur with that. For aws related hooks/operators we should have consistent naming convention. For instance, google hooks start with gcp_* filename and GoogleCloudHookname  For the same reason for dynamodb I merged aws_dynamodb_hook and for Kinesis https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2586 its aws_kinesis_hook filenames and AwsHookname.
Sounds good to me, I'll make a JIRA issue to address naming inconsistencies with current Aws hook extensions in order to follow that practice.
thanks @andyxhadji more power to #airflow and #aws

Hi @bolkedebruin, we have a few open issues but are getting close to having something ready for release. Would you be available for a chat with me (and @grantnicholas or @benjigoldberg if you guys have time) to discuss some of the outstanding issues/what steps we can start taking to prep for a release once these tickets are merged? Thank you!

For logging the last line- in testing on a local DAG it seemed to log everything, but that might have been luck from a race condition. I updated to grab and log all the client-side error lines using `readlines`.

With respect to server-side logs, currently they can at least be accessed from Cloud Logging or the Dataflow Cloud Console, but it would probably be useful in a future PR to add a GCP Logging hook. That way, GCP logs could optionally be polled as part of any GCP operator as the operator executes. The hook could include options like severity and filter.
@Fokko not sure how this `pip install -e` thing works in my local, as I am not able to reproduce the error you got. Anyway I've updated it now, plz check.

Thanks @msumit 

It works now:
```
root@6bdd99f4ffb2:/airflow# nosetests  tests/contrib/sensors/test_qubole_sensor.py
...
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 3 tests in 0.011s

OK
```

Currently I'm still waiting for my Apache ID to be verified, maybe @bolkedebruin is in the position to merge
Thanks @Fokko
@dimberman sure I can give some guidelines, but maybe you would like to include some others as well? We are an open shift user so others have more input to the discussion maybe?
@jgao54 addressed comments!
@bolkedebruin This is now reviewable, all tests are passing. Please take a look!

@bolkedebruin Sure! The questions I have are mostly just about the PR itself (i.e. should we rebase this branch or create a new branch with a cleaner commit history, should we try to break the branch into smaller PRs). Do you think this should be a meeting announced on the user list, or are you more  thinking someone from the kubernetes side?
Note, this is one of the follow-ups to https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2532
This is one of the follow-ups to https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2532

Hi @tgs 

This variable is "explained" [here](https://airflow.apache.org/code.html#default-variables) in the tutorial.

Cherry picked into v1-9-test
lgtm
LGTM but will defer to @saguziel for a final signoff

That's the API reference, not the tutorial.  The reason I suggested the change is that I had no idea what the variable was when looking in the tutorial, and I had to find that page to get an explanation.  The API reference isn't the first google result for "apache airflow ds", and it's hard to Ctrl-F find "ds" on that page because "ds" occurs in lots of other words.
You right then. Maybe you can note that it's the **execution date** to be more specific.

Hello. we are also interested in this feature. 

You add directly a git-sync into the kubernetes executor, I imagine this will be handled by the executor image (git-sync is writen in go, except if you use the python version of git-sync). Isn't it possible to split it to another PR so this feature can become available to any kind of executor (especially Celery)?

I am working on the Helm integration of Airflow in Kubernetes (see my [PR](https://github.com/mumoshu/kube-airflow/pull/16) here, who also uses git-sync :) ). If you agree we can work together to stress this Kubernetes executor for help integration in mainline.

Started a mail chain about reverting this commit from the master. 

cc - @criccomini @Fokko @mistercrunch @r39132 and @bolkedebruin
+1 Deleting a DAG is a good thing to have

Any reason this was closed? Doesn't seem to be merged.

@gwax addressed your comments

@saguziel I updated the PR to only fail QUEUED tasks. I'm not convinced we should ignore RUNNING, as it is inconsistent with Backfills and I don't like that we are ignoring executor state here which functions as a monitor. But if it takes that to have it pass for now lets do that.

LGTM
@fenglu-g I am fine with the current env variable way. Also, +1 to Bolke's suggestion to provide example/documentation on how to use this backend.

Hello. I joined the slack, i'll be happy to chat with you guys, I have several questions regarding bringing our airflow to production.
I think there will be 2 helm charts, one for celery one for this patch, like I said on the my PR. merging it requires the release of the new Airflow with this PR + mine (#2723 about url_prefix).
I like git-sync, it does it's job perfectly but I am a little worried about how to gate it with unit tests. Maybe with a protected branch? But in my case I had to make it run in background in the worker, without any watchdog to restart it. Maybe I'll switch to S6/init-containers. I don't want to force people to use persistant storage (so with a sidecar container that only does the git replication).

Don't hesitate to add comment on my PR [kube-airflow#16](https://github.com/mumoshu/kube-airflow/pull/16) if your internal charts does more stuff. 

Also you tell that helm cannot be used by anyone? Can you elaborate? Isn't it in a path to become the defactor standard for production deployment of applications in kubernetes?

Hi @bolkedebruin. Hope you are doing great. I am sure you are pretty busy over there but I just wanted to reach out to see if you are ok with maintaining the two commits separated to keep the ownership of the work done in each one of them by different developers. Many thanks again!

EDIT: tagging @mistercrunch, @artwr and @skudriashev as suggested by the bot.
